taskDescription:
There are approximately <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow>
  <mn>1</mn>
  <mo>×<!-- × --></mo>
  <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
    <msup>
      <mn>10</mn>
      <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
        <mn>12</mn>
      </mrow>
    </msup>
  </mrow>
</mrow><annotation encoding="LaTeX">1 \times {10^{12}}</annotation></semantics></math> grains of sand in a cubic meter. If the number of grains of sand on the Australian coastline is roughly <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow>
  <mn>7.5</mn>
  <mo>×<!-- × --></mo>
  <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
    <msup>
      <mn>10</mn>
      <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
        <mn>21</mn>
      </mrow>
    </msup>
  </mrow>
</mrow><annotation encoding="LaTeX">7.5 \times {10^{21}}</annotation></semantics></math> grains, roughly how many cubic meters of sand is there on the Australian coastline?
